abstract: A method for optimizing the scanning process of a mobile terminal, the scanning process being performed by the mobile terminal in order to discover an available network to which a connection is possible, wherein at least a part of existing networks is registered to a server, wherein the server provides its information regarding the registered networks to the mobile terminal, is characterized in that the scanning period of the mobile terminal is dynamically adjusted on the basis of information provided by the server.

title: System and method for training a multi-class support vector machine to select a common subset of features for classifying objects
abstract: An improved system and method is provided for training a multi-class support vector machine to select a common subset of features for classifying objects. A multi-class support vector machine generator may be provided for learning classification functions to classify sets of objects into classes and may include a sparse support vector machine modeling engine for training a multi-class support vector machine using scaling factors by simultaneously selecting a common subset of features iteratively for all classes from sets of features representing each of the classes. An objective function using scaling factors to ensure sparsity of features may be iteratively minimized, and features may be retained and added until a small set of features stabilizes. Alternatively, a common subset of features may be found by iteratively removing at least one feature simultaneously for all classes from an active set of features initialized to represent the entire set of training features.

title: Device, system and method of debugging computer programs
abstract: Device, system, and method of debugging computer programs. For example, a method for debugging computer programs includes: locating a bug in a computer program based on a first score corresponding to a first instrumentation location of the computer program and a second score corresponding to a second instrumentation location of the computer program.

title: A handover mechanism that exploits an uplink channel quality of a target cell
abstract: 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 DESCRIPTION A handover mechanism that exploits an uplink channel quality of a target cell BACKGROUND I. Field [0001] The present specification refers in general to wireless communications, and more particularly, to a transfer mechanism or mechanisms for transferring a mobile terminal in a wireless communication system. II. Background [0002] Conventional technologies used to transmit information within a mobile communications network (for example, a mobile telephone network) include techniques based on frequency, time and code division. In general, with techniques based on frequency division, calls are split based on a frequency access procedure, in which the respective calls are placed on a different frequency. With time-based techniques, a certain portion of time is assigned to the respective calls on a designated frequency. With the techniques based on the division of code, the respective calls are associated with unique codes and propagated by the available frequencies. The respective technologies can accommodate multiple accesses of one or more users. [0003] More particularly, frequency division-based techniques typically separate the spectrum into different channels by dividing it into uniform bandwidth segments; For example, the division of the assigned frequency band for wireless mobile telephone communication can be divided into 30 channels, each of which can carry a voice conversation or, with digital service, carry digital data. Each channel can be assigned to only one user at a time. A commonly used variant is an orthogonal frequency division technique that effectively divides the total system bandwidth into multiple orthogonal subbands. These subbands are also called tones, carriers, subcarriers, bins and frequency channels. Each subband is associated with a subcarrier that can be modulated with data. With time-based techniques, a band is divided into time in sequential time slots or time slots. Each user of a channel is provided with a time interval to transmit and receive information in "round-robin" mode. For example, at any given time t, a user is provided access to the channel during a short burst. Next, access changes to another user who is given a short time burst to transmit and receive information. The "take turns" cycle continues and, finally, multiple bursts of transmission and reception are provided to each user. [0004] The techniques based on the division of code typically transmit data through a number of frequencies available at any time in an interval. In general, the data is digitized and propagated by the available bandwidth, in which multiple users can overlap on the channel and a unique sequence code can be assigned to the respective users. Users can transmit in the same broadband segment of the spectrum, in which the signal of each user is propagated throughout the bandwidth by means of their respective unique propagation code. This technique can provide sharing, in which one or more users can transmit and receive simultaneously. Such sharing can be achieved by a digital modulation in spread spectrum, in which the bit stream of a user is encoded and propagated through a very wide channel in a pseudo-random manner. The receiver is designed to recognize the associated unique sequence code and undo the randomization in order to collect the bits for a particular user in a consistent manner. [0005] A typical wireless communication network (for example, employing frequency, time and code division techniques) includes one or more base stations that provide a coverage area and one or more mobile terminals (for example, wireless ) that can transmit and receive data within the coverage area. A typical base station can simultaneously transmit multiple data streams for broadcasting, multicast and / or unicast services, in which a data stream is a data stream that is of interest to be independently received for a mobile terminal. A mobile terminal within the coverage area of that base station may be interested in receiving one, more than one or all of the data streams carried by the composite stream. Also, a mobile terminal can transmit data to the base station or to another mobile terminal. Such communication between the base station and the mobile terminal or between mobile terminals may be degraded due to channel variations and / or interference power variations. For example, the mentioned variations may affect the programming of the base station, the power control and / or the prediction of the speed for one or more mobile terminals. [0006] In the preceding wireless communication systems, handover decisions are typically based on downlink channel (DL) quality metrics, for substantially any suitable metric, between the destination base station and the access terminal that is will pass. Said conventional approach to handover resolution does not incorporate uplink channel (UL) quality indications of the target cell. However, UL and dL in a typical wireless communication design may have characteristics 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 substantially disparate and, therefore, present an imbalance between the quality of the transmission and reception of UL and DL, generally referred to as link imbalance. In addition, disparate propagation environments for the UL and DL signal can cause other disparities in the quality of UL and DL channels. Therefore, handover decisions that are based only on a set of DL quality indications of a destination base station may be inadequate, especially in cases where the link quality imbalance is such that the condition of the DL channel may be above a threshold for handover, but UL channel conditions may be below that threshold. There is therefore a need in the art for a transfer mechanism or mechanisms that are based on the quality of DL and UL channel. [0007] WO 01/01720 refers to a transfer evaluated by the network assisted by mobile and base stations. The transfer determination is made by the quality of uplink and downlink communication between a mobile station MS and a first base station BS1 as compared to a second mobile station BS2. As the mobile station moves, it measures the BCH downlink conditions of a third base station BS3. The MS reports those measurement profiles from the downlink to an RNC radio network controller whenever the profile of a nearby cell exceeds a standard. The RNC informs the base station, such as BS3, that an MS has identified the base station as a possible base station for current or short-term communication. The RNC gives BS3 the instruction to measure the uplink transmission power received from the MS as it moves. At first, power control is only provided between MS and BS3 until BS3 informs the RNC that the uplink from MS is at an appropriate level. SUMMARY [0008] The aforementioned need is satisfied by the independent claims. The advantageous embodiments are contained in the dependent claims. [0009] A simplified summary is presented below in order to provide a basic understanding of some aspects of the disclosed embodiments. This summary is not an exhaustive overview and is not intended to identify key or critical elements or delimit the scope of such modes of realization. Its purpose is to present some concepts of the ways of realization described in a simplified way as a prelude to the more detailed description that will be presented later. [0010] The system or systems and the procedure or procedures are provided for the transfer of a mobile terminal in a wireless communication system. The handover resolution is based on a downlink channel quality indication between a server base station and the mobile terminal, and uplink channel quality indications between the terminal and a measurement set of the destination base stations . To generate UL channel quality indicators, the mobile station carries a narrow-band or broadband polling reference signal, and the server and destination base stations measure performance metrics of UL and DL (for example, power received from the reference signal (RSRP), intensity indicator of the reference signal (RSSI) or reference signal on thermal noise (RSOT). In reverse handover, the UL channel status information from the target cells is received at the serving base station through the return communication, and the handover is resolved based on the UL and DL quality reports. In the direct handover, the set of UL quality reports are transported to the mobile station to determine a destination cell for the handover. [0011] In one aspect, a procedure for facilitating handover in a wireless system is disclosed, the procedure comprising: receiving a set of uplink channel (UL) quality metrics through a return communication interface; generate a UL channel quality metric; receive a set of downlink channel conditions; resolve the transfer based, at least in part, on the UL and DL channel quality indications received. [0012] In another aspect, the present specification describes a wireless device, comprising: a processor configured to receive a set of uplink channel quality reports through a point-to-point backbone network communication; receive a set of downlink channel condition indicators through a wireless link; establish a transfer based, at least in part, on the received UL channel quality reports and DL channel condition indicators; and a memory coupled to the processor. [0013] In another aspect, an apparatus that operates in a wireless environment is disclosed, the apparatus comprising: means for receiving a set of uplink channel (UL) quality metrics through a return communication interface; means for generating an indication of UL channel quality; means for receiving a set of downlink channel (DL) conditions; and means for resolving the handover based, at least in part, on the UL channel quality metrics received and the set of DL channel quality indications. [0014] In a further aspect, the present specification describes a computer program product 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 comprising a means readable by a computer that includes: a code to make at least one computer receive a set of uplink channel (UL) quality reports through a return communication interface; a code to make at least one computer generate a metric of UL channel quality; receive a set of downlink channel (DL) metrics; establish a transfer based, at least in part, on the set of UL channel quality reports and the set of DL channel metrics. [0015] In one aspect, the present specification describes a procedure for facilitating handover in a wireless system, the method comprising: receiving uplink channel quality metrics (UL); save a transfer fitness score associated with a source of the received UL channel quality metrics; establish a transfer based, at least in part, on the UL channel metrics received and the channel quality metrics saved. [0016] In another aspect, the present specification discloses an apparatus operating in a wireless environment, the apparatus comprising: a processor configured to receive a set of uplink channel (UL) quality indicators; transport a probing reference signal; generate a set of downlink channel condition reports; resolve a transfer based, at least in part, on the set of UL channel metrics received; and a memory coupled to the processor. [0017] In another aspect, a wireless device is disclosed, the device comprising: means for receiving an uplink channel (UL) metric; means for determining a set of downlink channel (DL) conditions; means for storing a pass-through fitness score associated with a source of the received UL channel metric; means for establishing a transfer based, at least in part, on the received UL channel metric; and means for resolving a handover based, at least in part, on the metric of the received UL channel and the saved handover rating. [0018] In a further aspect, the present specification discloses a computer program product comprising a means readable by a computer that includes: a code to make at least one computer receive an uplink channel (UL) metric; a code to make at least one computer save a transfer fitness score associated with a source of the received UL channel metric; a code to make at least one computer determine a transfer based, at least in part, on the received UL channel metric; and a code to make at least one computer solve a handover based, at least in part, on the metric of the received UL channel and the saved handover rating. [0019] For the attainment of the foregoing and related purposes, one or more embodiments comprise the features that are described in their entirety below and which are particularly pointed out in the claims. The following description and the accompanying drawings set out in detail certain illustrative aspects and are a sample of some of the various ways in which the principles of the embodiments can be used. Other advantages and novel features will become apparent from the following detailed description when considered together with the drawings, and the disclosed embodiments are intended to include all these aspects and their equivalents. BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE DRAWINGS [0020] FIG. 1 illustrates an example multiple access wireless communication system in accordance with various aspects set forth herein. A wireless terminal may refer to a device that provides voice and / or data connectivity to a user. A wireless terminal can be connected to an information device, such as a laptop or desktop computer, or it can be an autonomous device, such as a personal digital assistant (PDA). A wireless terminal can also be called a system, subscriber unit, subscriber station, mobile station, mobile terminal, mobile, remote station, access point, remote terminal, access terminal, user terminal, user agent, user device or User equipment A wireless terminal can be a subscriber station, wireless device, mobile phone, PCS phone, wireless phone, session initiation protocol (SIP) telephone, wireless local loop station (WLL), personal digital assistant (PDA), device Portable with wireless connection capability or other processing device connected to a wireless modem. [0025] A base station may refer to a device in an access network that communicates through the air interface, through one or more sectors, with wireless terminals, and with other base stations via return network communication. The base station can act as a router between the wireless terminal and the rest of the access network, which can include an IP network, converting the received air interface frames into IP packets. The base station also coordinates the management of attributes for the air interface. In addition, various embodiments are described in this document in relation to a base station. A base station can 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 used to communicate with a mobile device or devices and may also be called an access point, Node B, Node B evolved (eNodeB), or some other terminology. [0026] Referring below to the drawings, FIG. 1 is an illustration of a multiple access wireless communication system 100 according to various aspects. In one example, the multiple access wireless communication system 100 includes multiple base stations 110 and multiple terminals 120. In addition, one or more base stations 110 may communicate with one or more terminals 120. By way of non-limiting example, a base station 110 may be an access point, a Node B and / or other appropriate network entity. Each base station 110 provides communication coverage for a particular geographic area 102a-c. As used herein and in general in the art, the term "cell" may refer to a base station 110 and / or its coverage area 102a-c depending on the context in which the term is used. [0027] To improve the capacity of the system, the coverage area 102a, 102b or 102c corresponding to a base station 110 can be partitioned into multiple smaller areas (for example, areas 104a, 104b and 104c). Each of the smaller areas 104a, 104b and 104c can be serviced by a respective base transceiver subsystem (BTS, not shown). As used herein and in general in the art, the term "sector" may refer to a BTS and / or its coverage area, depending on the context in which the term is used. In one example, sectors 104a, 104b, 104c of a cell 102a, 102b, 102c may be formed by groups of antennas (not shown) in base station 110, in which each group of antennas is responsible for communicating with terminals 120 in a portion of cell 102a, 102b or 102c. For example, a base station 110 serving cell 102a may have a first group of antennas corresponding to sector 104a, a second group of antennas corresponding to sector 104b and a third group of antennas corresponding to sector 104c. However, it should be appreciated that the various aspects disclosed in this document can be used in a system that has sectorized and / or non-sectorized cells. In addition, it should be noted that all suitable wireless communication networks that have any number of sectorized and / or non-sectorized cells belong to the scope of the claims attached to this document. For simplicity, the expression "base station" as used herein may refer to both to a station that serves a sector, and to a station that serves a cell. As it used herein, a "service" access point is one with which a terminal has transmissions of uplink traffic (data), and a "near" access point (which does not service) is one with which a terminal may have downlink traffic and / or uplink and uplink transmissions, but not uplink traffic. It should be noted that, as used herein, a downlink sector in a disjoint link scenario is a nearby sector. Although the following description generally refers to a system in which each terminal communicates with a service access point for reasons of simplicity, it should be appreciated that the terminals can communicate with any number of service access points. [0028] According to one aspect, terminals 120 may be scattered throughout the system 100. Each terminal 120 may be fixed or mobile. By way of non-limiting example, a terminal 120 may be an access terminal (AT), a mobile station, a user equipment, a subscriber station and / or another appropriate network entity. A terminal 120 may be a wireless device, a mobile phone, a personal digital assistant (PDA), a wireless modem, a portable device or other appropriate device. In addition, terminals 120 can communicate with any number of base stations 110 or with no base station 110 at any given time. [0029] In another example, the system 100 can use a centralized architecture using a system controller 130 that can be coupled to one or more base stations 110 and provide coordination and control for the base stations 110. According to alternative aspects, the controller System 130 can be a single network entity or a group of network entities. In addition, the system 100 can use a distributed architecture to allow the base stations 110 to communicate with each other as necessary. The return network communication 135 can facilitate point-to-point communication between base stations using such distributed architecture. In one example, system controller 130 may also contain one or more connections to multiple networks. These networks may include the Internet, other packet-based networks and / or circuit switched voice networks that can provide information to and / or from terminals 120 in communication with one or more base stations 110 in system 100. In another example, system controller 130 may include or be coupled to a programmer (not shown) that can schedule transmissions to and / or from terminals 120. Alternatively, the programmer may reside in each individual cell 102, each sector 104, or a combination thereof. [0030] In one example, the system 100 may use one or more multiple access schemes, such as CDMA, TDMA, FDMA, OfDmA, single carrier FDMA (SC-FDMA) and / or other suitable multiple access schemes. TDMA uses time division multiplexing (TDM), in which transmissions for different terminals 120 are orthogonalized by transmission at different time intervals. FDMA uses frequency division multiplexing (FDM), in which the transmissions for different terminals 120 are orthogonalized by transmission in different frequency subcarriers. In one example, TDMA and FDMA systems can also use code division multiplexing (CDM), in which transmissions for multiple terminals can 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 orthogonalized by different orthogonal codes (for example, Walsh codes) even if they are wrapped in the same time interval or subcarrier of frequency. OFDMA uses orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM), and SC-FDMA uses single carrier frequency division multiplexing (SC-FDM). OFDM and SC-FDM can partition the system bandwidth into multiple orthogonal subcarriers (for example, tones, bins, ...), each of which can be modulated with data. Typically, the modulation symbols are sent in the frequency domain with OFDM and in the time domain with SC-FDM. In addition and / or alternatively, the system bandwidth can be divided into one or more frequency carriers, each of which may contain one or more subcarriers. System 100 can also use a combination of multiple access schemes, such as OFDMA and CDMA. Although the power control techniques provided herein are generally described for an OFDMA system, it should be appreciated that the techniques described herein can be applied in a similar manner to any wireless communication system. [0031] In another example, base stations 110 and terminals 120 of system 100 can communicate data through one or more data channels and signaling through one or more control channels. The data channels used by the system 100 can be assigned to the active terminals 120 so that each data channel is used by a single terminal at any given time. Alternatively, data channels can be assigned to multiple terminals 120, which can be superimposed or programmed orthogonally on a data channel. To conserve system resources, the control channels used by the system 100 can also be shared between multiple terminals 120 by, for example, code division multiplexing. In one example, data channels orthogonally multiplexed only in frequency and time (for example, data channels not multiplexed by CDM) may be less susceptible to loss of orthogonality due to channel conditions and receiver imperfections than channels. corresponding control. [0032] FIGs. 2A, 2B and 2C are, respectively, a block diagram of an example system that facilitates handover based on UL and DL channel conditions in accordance with aspects described herein; UL and DL measurement diagrams, and communication indicators carried during the operation of the system of FIG. 2A; and a block diagram of an example system that facilitates handover based on UL and DL channel conditions. [0033] FIG. 2A is a block diagram 200 of an example system that facilitates the direct transfer of a mobile station. In system 200, a service node 210 includes a CQI generator 212 and a sequence generator 214. Such components facilitate the generation of downlink (DL) broadband or narrowband downlink reference signals, which can be transmitted to the equipment. of user 230 for the generation of channel quality indications through the CQI 232 generator; The CQI of DL 226 is notified to eNode B 210 of service. The generation of DL channel conditions can be carried out periodically, the notification period of CQI can be determined by the traffic and the load in a cell that is covered by service eNode B 210. In addition, the notification period may depend on the notified DL channel conditions, in order to ensure that the precise DL 226 CQI is received in the service eNode B 210. In addition, the generation and notification of CQI of DL 226 can be activated by event, for example, an additional wireless device enters the coverage area of eNode B 210, an access terminal in a nearby cell transmits a burst of data that increases substantially Another interference from the sector increases the size of a data buffer (for example, which resides in memory 218) and the communication resources for UE 230, or a disparate UE, need an adjustment, etc. [0034] In addition to receiving the DL 226 CQI from the UE 230, the service eNode B receives a reference polling signal (SRS) from UL 228, which can be a sequence transmitted in a narrow band (eg, 1 , 08 MHz, as in the case of a RACH sounding signal) or a broadband. (It should be noted that the UL sRs is generated by the sequence generator 234, which operates in substantially the same way as the sequence generator 214.) The probe signal is used by the service eNode B 210 to carry out measurements of UL channel conditions (for example, signal strength, C / I ratios, and the like), which can be used as a reference metric in a handover algorithm, which can reside in memory 222 and can be executed by the processor 216 to resolve the handover of UE 230 according to aspects that will be analyzed later. A UL channel condition report can be stored in memory 218 if necessary. The UL measurements on the service eNode B can be carried out by the CQI 212 generator, which functions as the CQI 232 generator. [0035] In one aspect, user equipment 230 also transports the SRS of UL 2421-242n to a set of destination nodes 2501-250n (N: a positive integer). Each of the destination base stations 2501-250N can use the received UL polling channels to perform UL measurements and determine a UL channel condition report. Once the UL 262 measurements have been completed, the results are transported to service eNode B 210. In one aspect, said communication occurs through the return network 260, or interface X2 in LTE. In this way, the service eNode B 210 can have access to the UL channel conditions, for the UL belonging to the service node and for the UL belonging to the measurement set of the destination eNode Bs 2501-250n-. It should be appreciated that the uplink channel status information and the DL channel quality estimates are available for the service eNode 210. Therefore, using an algorithm of 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 handover in memory 222, service base station 210 can resolve the handover of user equipment 230 based, at least in part, on UL and DL channel quality information. It should be noted that the latter can remedy issues such as the UL / DL link imbalance and can also take into account the different transfer limits for UL and DL, particularly in cases where the signal on these channels is propagated differently as in the case of FDD systems with a substantial disparity in operating frequencies. [0036] In another aspect, the server base station 210 can carry the {SRS of UL} i-n 266 generated by the user equipment 230, and the {communication indicators} 1-N 264 comprising various system information. It should be appreciated that (i) providing UL SRS through a return communication can reduce cellular traffic, which is beneficial for the QoS of disparate access terminals. In addition, in case of poor channel conditions, point-to-point communication through return 260 ensures adequate reception in the destination cells. In addition, the transport of said system information facilitates the indirect presynchronization, or the approximate synchronization, of the eNode Bs of destination 2501-250n with the user equipment 230, to prepare for the handover. The UL and DL measurements and the communicator indicators broadcast through the return network are presented below. Memories 218 and 238 can save respective data structures, code instructions, algorithms, and the like, which can be used by the respective processors 216 and 236 when they confer to the base station 210 or the UE 230 their functionality. In system 300, a user equipment comprises a handover component 315 that can resolve (for example, grant or deny) the handover to destination eNode B 380. To grant or deny a handover, the UE 310 generates reference signals of UL 377 probing through sequence generator 325 in substantially the same manner as discussed above in relation to sequence generator 234. In one aspect, the SRS of UL 377 is transported at a power greater than AP dBm with respect to to a reference signal transported to the EU service signal, to ensure that the propagation of the UL SRS encompasses several levels of the nearby eNode Bs (eg, destination eNode B 380). As discussed above, UL SRS can be transmitted through a narrowband channel, for example, RACH in LTE, for a specific period, such as M subframes or Q slots. Also, to avoid collisions, disparate UEs can transmit UL SRS in disparate time-frequency resources; Typically, it is desired to avoid the collision since it can mitigate the degradation of the typical battery associated with the transport of the reference signals. [0043] The SRS reference signals of UL 377 are used by a CQI 385 generator to estimate, for example, by measurements, the UL channel conditions (eg RSRP, RSSI or RSOT) that are notified to UE 310 in the downlink as CQIul 379. To improve the estimates of the channel condition made by the CQI generator 385, the UE 310 can repeat the UL SRS up to P times; however, the transfer component 315 can limit the value of P to a maximum value P max which ensures adequate compensation between the advantage of receiving more accurate CQIul reports and the capacity, or traffic flow, of the cell / sector, and the battery costs associated with increasing the cell charge by substantive repetition of the UL SRS sequence. In one aspect, the handover component 315 may be based on an intelligent component (not shown) to adaptively find an optimal Pmax value based, at least in part, on changes in cell / sector interference, traffic and metrics of load. In an alternative or additional aspect, in order to avoid undue loading of a narrowband or broadband channel carrying the SRS of UL 377, the UE 310 may be based on an HO (a) fitness score associated with an eNode B of destination 380, so that the SRS of UL 377 is transmitted in cases where a> aTH, where aTH is the punctuation threshold. Such punctuation can be adapted, increasing or decreasing, according to notified UL channel conditions, for example, cQIul379. Five fifty 55 60 65 Node B 210) and a receiver system 450 (for example, access terminal 230) in a system of multiple inputs and multiple outputs (MIMO) that can provide communication of cells (or sectors) in a wireless environment according to one or more aspects presented in this document. In the transmitter system 410, traffic data can be provided for a number of data streams from a data source 412 to a transmission data processor (TX) 414. In one embodiment, each data stream is transmitted through of a respective transmission antenna. The TX 414 data processor formats, encodes and interleaves the traffic data for each data stream based on a particular coding scheme selected for that data stream to provide encoded data. The encoded data for each data stream can be multiplexed with pilot data using OFDM techniques. Pilot data is typically a known data pattern that is processed in a known manner and that can be used in the receiving system to estimate the channel response. Next, the multiplexed pilot and encoded data for each data stream is modulated (for example, the assignment of symbols) based on a particular modulation scheme (e.g., binary phase shift modulation (BPSK), quadrature phase shift modulation (QPSK), multiple phase shift modulation (M-PSK) or multilevel quadrature amplitude modulation (M-QAM) selected for that data flow to provide modulation symbols. The speed, coding and modulation of data for each data stream can be determined by instructions executed by the processor 430, the instructions as well as the data can be stored in memory 432. [0049] Next, the modulation symbols for all data streams are provided to a MIMO TX 420 processor, which can further process the modulation symbols (eg, OFDM). Next, the MIMO TX 420 processor provides Nt modulation symbol streams to the Nt transceivers (TMTR / RCVR) 422a to 422t. In certain embodiments, the MIMO TX 420 processor applies beam conformation weights (or precoding) to the symbols of the data streams and to the antenna from which the symbol is being transmitted. Each transceiver 422 receives and processes a respective flow of symbols to provide one or more analog signals and also treats (for example, amplifies, filters and performs the upstream conversion of) the analog signals to provide a modulated signal suitable for transmission through MIMO channel. Next, the modulated Nt signals of transceivers 422a to 422t are transmitted from the Nt antennas 4241 to 424t, respectively. In the receiver system 450, the transmitted modulated signals are received by the Nr antennas 4521 to 452r and the signal received from each antenna 452 is provided to a respective transceiver (RCVR / TMTR) 454a to 454r. Each 4541-454r transceiver treats (for example, filters, amplifies and performs the down conversion of) a respective received signal, digitizes the treated signal to provide samples and further processes the samples to provide a corresponding flow of "received" symbols. [0050] Next, an RX 460 data processor receives and processes the Nr symbol streams received from the Nr transceivers 4541-454r based on a particular receiver processing technique to provide Nt streams of "detected" symbols. Next, the RX 660 data processor demodulates, deinterleaves and decodes each symbol stream detected to retrieve the traffic data for the data stream. The processing of the RX 460 data processor is complementary to that performed by the MIMO TX 620 processor and the TX 414 data processor in the transmitter system 410. A 470 processor periodically determines which precoding matrix to use; such an array can be stored in memory 672. The processor 670 formulates a reverse link message comprising a matrix index portion and a range value portion. Memory 472 can store instructions that, when executed by processor 670, result in the formulation of the reverse link message. The reverse link message may comprise various types of information regarding the communication link and / or the flow of data received, or a combination thereof. In particular, said information may comprise a report or channel quality indicator reports (such as CQI of DL 226 or {UL measurements} 1-n 262), a lag to adjust a scheduled resource or probing reference signals for the estimate of the link (or channel). Next, the reverse link message is processed by a TX 438 data processor, which also receives traffic data for a number of data streams from a data source 436, modulated by a modulator 480, treated by transceivers 454a to 454r and transmitted back to transmitter system 410. [0051] In the transmitter system 410, the modulated signals of the receiver system 450 are received by the antennas 4241-624t, treated by the transceivers 422a-422t, demodulated by a demodulator 440 and processed by an RX 442 data processor to extract the Reverse link message transmitted by the receiving system 450. Next, the processor 430 determines which precoding matrix to use to determine the weights of the beam conformation and processes the extracted message. [0052] A mobile station 230 can be programmed to operate in SIMO, SU-MIMO and MU-MIMO, depending at least in part on the channel quality indicators notified by said receiver. Next, the communication in these modes of operation is described. It is observed that in the SIMo mode a single antenna is used in the receiver (N r = 1) for communication; Therefore, SIMO operation can be interpreted as a special case of SU-MIMO. The single user MIMO mode of operation corresponds to the case in which a single receiver system 450 communicates with the transmitter system 610, as illustrated above in FIG. 4 and in accordance with the operation described in relation thereto. In such a system, the Nt transmitters 4241-424t (also known as TX antennas) and the Nr receivers 4521-452r (also known as RX antennas) form a MIMO matrix channel (e.g., Rayleigh channel, or Gaussian channel, with slow fade or fast) to 5 10 fifteen twenty 25 30 35 40 Four. Five fifty 55 60 65 Wireless communication As mentioned above, the SU-MIMO channel is described by an NrxNt matrix of random complex numbers. The channel range is equal to the algebraic range of the NrxNt matrix, which in terms of space-time, or spatial frequency coding, the range is equal to the number Nv ^ min {NT, Nr} of data streams (or layers ) independent that can be sent through the SU-MIMO channel without causing interference between flows. [0053] In one aspect, in the SU-MIMO mode, the symbols transmitted / received with OFDM, in the tone w, can be modeled by: and (w) - H (to) c (co) + n (co). (2) Here, and (w) is the data stream received and is a vector Nrx1, H (w) is the channel response matrix NrxNt in the tone w (for example, the Fourier transform of the dependent channel response matrix of time h), c (w) is an output symbol vector Ntx1, and n (w) is a noise vector Nrx1 (for example, additive Gaussian white noise). The precoding can convert an Nvx1 layer vector into an Ntx1 precoding output vector. Nv is the actual number of data streams (layers) transmitted by transmitter 410 and Nv can be programmed at the discretion of the transmitter (for example, transmitter 410, Node B 410 or access point 210) based, at least in part, on conditions channel (for example, CQI notified according to a notification approach established by a service access point) and the range notified in a programming request by a terminal (for example, receiver 450). It should be noted that c (w) is the result of at least one multiplexing scheme, and at least one precoding scheme (or beam formation) applied by the transmitter. In addition, c (w) can be convolved with a power gain matrix, which determines the amount of power that transmitter 410 allocates to transmit each data stream Nv. It should be appreciated that such a power gain matrix can be a resource that is assigned to a terminal (for example, access terminal 230, receiver 450 or UE 230) through a programmer in the service node in response, at least in party, to a notified CQI.
